_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The management and staff of the Tracy Distribution Center are committed to operating the Distribution Center with the highest regard for the safety of the public, Distribution Center personnel, and the environment.  To ensure the safety of the public, Distribution Center personnel, and the environment, the Distribution Center has implemented a management system that integrates the elements of Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, 8 CCR 5189, EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule, 40 CFR part 68, and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  The policies and procedures integrated under the Distribution Center's management system specifically address prevention of the release of anhydrous ammonia, and emergency response to an accidental release of ammonia.

B.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Tracy Distribution Center operates several refrigerated warehouses and freezers.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the mechanical compression refrigeration system at the Tracy Distribution Center.  Ammonia is handled in a closed-loop process that consists of the following general stages: liquid storage; expansion; evaporation; compression; and condensation.

The ammonia refrigeration system is the only process at the Tracy Distribution Center which is subject to the EPA RMP rule ( and the Cal-OSHA PSM standard).  Anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled in the ammonia refrigeration system.

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the high pressure thermosyphon receiver to the two controlled pressure receivers where the pressure is dropped to 65 and 45 psig.  The thermosyphon receiver also supplies ammonia to the compressors for oil cooling.  From the 65 psig controlled pressure receiver, liquid ammonia is transferred to dock evaporators, a glycol chil

ler, ice production makers, produce and meat storage areas, and the new Perishables Warehouse (2001).  The 45 psig controlled pressure receiver transfers liquid ammonia to the freezer evaporators.  A liquid/vapor mixture is pulled from these pieces of equipment to individual suction accumulators.  Dock evaporators and the glycol chiller send a liquid/vapor mixture to the +30?F Suction Accumulator, and the produce and meat storage area evaporators send a mixture to the +15?F Suction Accumulator.  The appropriate level of liquid is maintained in each accumulator by dump traps that pump liquid from the accumulators to the controlled pressure receivers.  The +30? and +15? accumulator's associated dump trap delivers liquid to the 65 psig controlled pressure receiver.  -25? accumulator delivers liquid to the 45 psig controlled pressure receiver. 

The vapor from the -25? Suction Accumulator is routed to the four Booster Compressors.  Discharge from these four compressors is sent by a common header to the 45 psig controlled pressure receiver.  Vapor from the +30? and +15? Suction Accumulators are routed to the nine compressors where the pressure and temperature of the gas is increased.  Compressor discharge (high pressure ammonia vapor, or hot gas) is sent to the condenser where it is condensed to a high pressure liquid and returned to the thermosyphon receiver.  An Auto Purger periodically purges the system of non-condensibles collected in the condenser.  The system also has an emergency refrigerant control box located outside of the machine room where pressure can be manually relieved from one vessel to another. 

C.  HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release Result Summary

The worst case release scenario is a release of the total quantity of ammonia in the largest vessel in the ammonia refrigeration system, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity in the vessel.  If a vessel is located inside a building, the EPA allows a passive m

itigation factor of 55% to be used in calculating the release rate to the outside atmosphere when the release is enclosed by a building.

The 65 psig Controlled Pressure Receiver results in the highest release rate, and will therefore be used for the worst case release scenario.  The vessel is located inside the building, so passive mitigation was considered.  The maximum ammonia release of 21,460 lbs. in 10 minutes is limited by the vessel size.  

Since the vessel is located in the engine room, the mitigated release rate is 1157 lbs./minute.

For analyzing the worst case release scenario, EPA requires the use of the most pessimistic meteorological conditions that will allow for the maximum downwind exposure.  Low wind speeds (1.5 m/s) and stable atmospheric conditions (F stability) will allow the gas cloud to travel as far as possible by limiting cloud dispersion.  The results are conservative.

EPA's "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration," November 1998, Exhibit 4-4 was used to find the downwind distance for the worst case release to 200 ppm in an rural setting.  The RMP*Comp? Model developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and EPA was used to prepare the data in this guidance document.  This guidance document provides data for ammonia refrigeration systems and will ensure consistency throughout the industry.

This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.  

Note: Item 2-6 is required to be reported to 1 significant-figure and is the mitigated release rate, where as item 2-5 is the total quantity and is reported to 2 significant figures.

Alternative Release Result Summary

A release of ammonia resulting from a 0.25 inch diameter hole in a pipe for one hour.  The release rate of ammonia due to the pressure of the tank is 128 pounds per minute.  The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters per second wind speed and D stability.

Reference tables in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in rural conditions.  This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.


Note: Item 3-6 is required to be reported to 1 significant figure.

D.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Tracy Distribution Center facility has many safety features, including those implemented on the ammonia refrigeration system.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with the State Office of Emergency Services' California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program as well as Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), and Federal EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP), Program 3 requirements.

The Tracy Distribution Center opened in April 1992 with major upgrades to the ammonia system in 1999 and 2001.  The ammonia refrigeration system at the Tracy Distribution Center facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include an ammonia diffusion tank, ammonia sensors in the machine room, penthouses, dock areas and Perishable Warehouse, pressure relief valves to protects vessels' integrity, and automatic shut down systems that prevent equipment damage and ammonia releases.  In the event of ammonia detection, audible and visual alarms are triggered throughout the facility. 

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar t

o a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."

E.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Over the past five years, the Tracy Distribution Center has not had any ammonia releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, or offsite evacuations.

F.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Tracy Distribution Center facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document, which is maintained at the facility.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the Tracy Fire Department and the local fire houses.  If necessary, the facility will call 9-1-1 to alert the local Police and Fire Departments.

Other responders will be called as needed, including the Tracy Fire Department.  If a release exceeds the federal reporting quantity of 100 pounds for ammonia, the National Response Center will be called.

The Tracy Distribution Center will be responsible for evacuating and ensuring the safety of its employees in case of an emergency evacuation.  Evacuation drills are performed at least annually.  Other training received by employees includes: ammonia awareness, what to do in case of emergency, and where to go when an evacuation is called. 

The following summarizes the notification procedures at the facility:

1.   First call 911 on an internal/land line phone for the Tracy Fire Department, Police Departments, and California Highway Patrol.

2.  Call the Governor's Office of Emergency Services (OES) Chemical Emergency Planning & Response Center 1-800-852-7550.

3.  If additional help is required for an ammonia spill or leak, the facilities can call Chemtrec - Manufacturing Chemists Association 1-800-424-9300.

4.  If an ammonia release exceeds 100 pounds (Federal Reportable Quantity CERCLA), call the National Response Center 1-800-424-8802 and the San Joaquin Office of Emergency Services, Hazardous Materials Division at 209-468-3969 for a release of any amount.

5.  If serious injuries or harmful exposures to workers occurs, call the nearest Cal/OSHA Field Office in Modesto at 209-576-6260 or the nearest Regional Office in San Francisco at 415-557-8640.

6.  If an employee ingests ammonia, the Poison Control Center can be reached 24 hours per day at 800-342-9293.

7.  If an ammonia release is significant enough to potentially cause odor complaints from neighboring facilities, contact the Environmental Health Services, Hazardous Materials Division at 209-468-3420.

8.  If an ammonia release spills into the sewer system, contact the Tracy Waste Water Treatment Plant at 209-831-4480.

G.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The initial Process Hazard Analysis, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility "What If" Walkthrough, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Tracy Distribution Center located at 16900 West Schulte Road in Tracy, California. Then in August 2001, this study was updated to include the 2001 warehouse expansion project.  Al mitigation measures from the 1999 analysis have been completed.  The only remaining items are from the 2001 addendum and are scheduled to be complete by October 2002.


R2001-04  Review the exhaust fan calculations / conditions and ensure that they get included in the Process Safety Information.

R2001-07  Review the ammonia detection system for the new warehouse to determine detection limits and corresponding actions (proposed to add 12 new sensors - one for every 6,000 square feet of warehouse space).  Verify that the ammonia detection system will isol

ate the alarming zones / coils. If not, consider building a spreadsheet in Logix and/or the emergency response plan to identify solenoid valves that should be closed in the event of an emergency via the Logix system.

R2001-08  Determine whether or not there will be an ammonia sensor in the relief valve common header.  If there is going to be a sensor in the relief valve common header, consider having a system to flush the common header so that ammonia vapor does not build up.  Also, determine the alarm levels and associated actions of the relief valve header ammonia sensor. 

R2001-11  Include in the emergency response plan, the name and telephone number of a pre-selected vendor that will dispose of the water/ammonia mixture following a release.
